results.title: Atoms and starlight
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
The use of spectroscopy and spectrum analysis have been vital when astronomers study the stars. The continous, emission and dark-line spectra have enabled scientists to determine the composition of stars and to modify the original classification of stars. Atoms of elements have their own unique “fingerprint’ spectrum which can be determined by studying the behaviour of photons and electrons. With the advances in fibre optics, spectographs can now measure many stars instead on one, and thus determine the nature of a group of celestial bodies within a galaxy.

results.title: The Origin of modern astronomy
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
The Greeks considered the Earth to be the centre of the universe. Ptolemy’s model of the universe lasted until Copernicus began to postulate that it was the Earth which moved around the sun. Due to his allegiance to the Church, Copernicus did not pursue his theories, but Galileo, was able, with the invention of the telescope, to support the Copernican model of the universe. His ideas were considered heretical by the Counter-Reformation Church, however they sowed the seeds for future observation and theories. The work of Kepler followed, and it is this work, supporting Copernicus and Galileo which bridged the gap between ancient and modern astronomy.

results.title: Peculiar galaxies
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 16 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
This episode discusses a peculiar type of galaxy called a Quasar. Quasars looked liked stars but did not have the same size, shape or spectrum as stars. They were extremely luminous and expanding away from us. Quasars are believed to be the cause of galaxies. Astronomers believe that the structure of a Quasar is an extremely bright nucleus of a galaxy and a central Black Hole which over time evolves into a “normal” galaxy.

results.title: The Sun
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
The sun is the most familiar star to us in our galaxy. It provides us with energy, light and heat and sustains life on the planet. Even though the possibility of reaching the sun seems in the realms of science fiction, astronomers know a great deal about the sun and can apply that knowledge to the study of other celestial bodies. This episode looks at the composition of the sun, phenomenon such as sunspots and solar flares and the internal structure of this medium sized yet most important star.

results.title: Newton, Einstein and gravity
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
Aristotle and Galileo were pioneers in the study of motion. From the Greek concept of natural and violent motion, came Galileo’s ideas about impetus and inertia. Scientists like Keppler further developed these ideas. However, Issac Newton, with his Laws on Motion and Universal Gravitation, altered the study of physics and astronomy forever. Newton was able to mathematically work out the effects of gravity, however he was unable to identify a cause. It was Albert Einstein with his theories of Relativity and Curved Space/Time dimensions which changed the way scientists perceived the Laws of Gravity and space travel. This episode examines these pioneers and their ideas.

This episode examines these pioneers and their ideas.

results.title: Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coast Community College
results.brief_description: This series examines the history and science of astronomy. It includes superb graphics, photographs and time-lapse footage from satellites and observatories, and leading scientists in the various fields of astronomy offer clear explanations and valuable information.

results.title: The Moon and Mercury
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 21 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
This two part episode looks at the planet Mercury which is closest to our Sun, and the Moon, our nearest celestial neighbour. Both these heavenly bodies are similar and size and appearance. They appear desolate and marked with craters, but are different in important ways. Mercury has a magnetic field and large solid iron core but the Moon does not. Mercury, despite its closeness to the sun, has Polar Ice Caps due to its orbit. This program also looks at the exploration of the Moon by astronauts in the 1970’s and includes footage of Apollo 11’s historic landing in 1969.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges

results.title: Will you join?
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Union Representative”.
A new man starts work in a warehouse and is immediately approached by the union representative and told that it is in his best interests to join the Union. This approach offends the new man and he decides to seek another job. This film is an examination of the union delegate’s role and his manner in recruiting members.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Gow, Don Murray and Film Australia

results.title: Changes in the office
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Union Representative”.
The female union representative approaches a company manager to find out whether or not automated office equipment is to be installed which will cause fifty percent of the staff to be made redundant. Focuses on the manner in which the union delegate approaches the manager and how well she fulfils her role in representing the staff. Suitable for tertiary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Gow, Don Murray and Film Australia
